user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_queue_auth_required_response3:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_queue_auth_required_response3 (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                   const char *realm,
                                   const char *opaque,
                                   const char *domain,
                                   struct MHD_Response *response,
                                   int signal_stale,
                                   enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiQOP mqop,
                                   enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 malgo3,
                                   int userhash_support,
                                   int prefer_utf8)
{
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;
  char *buf_ptr;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  buf_ptr = NULL;
  digest_setup_zero (&da);
  ret = queue_auth_required_response3_inner (connection,
                                             realm,
                                             opaque,
                                             domain,
                                             response,
                                             signal_stale,
                                             mqop,
                                             malgo3,
                                             userhash_support,
                                             prefer_utf8,
                                             &buf_ptr,
                                             &da);
  digest_deinit (&da);
  if (NULL != buf_ptr)
    free (buf_ptr);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided snippet. Items examined and why they are not flagged:
- _MHD_EXTERN: this is a macro name only. The source shown does not contain any compiler-specific keyword or attribute (for example __attribute__, __declspec, __extension__, typeof, asm, statement-expressions ({ ... }) or other documented compiler extensions). Without the macro definition, it is not possible to determine that a compiler extension is actually used, so it is not reported here.
- enum and struct usage (enum MHD_Result, enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiQOP, enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3, struct MHD_Connection, struct MHD_Response, struct DigestAlgorithm): all are standard C constructs.
- Standard library identifiers and functions (NULL, free, char *, pointers, function calls): standard C, not extensions.
- Control flow and function return: standard C.

If the _MHD_EXTERN macro expands (in included headers or compiler command-line) to a compiler-specific extension (for example __attribute__((...)) or __declspec(...)), that expansion would need to be inspected; based solely on the shown code there is no guaranteed use of a documented compiler language extension, so no fragments are reported.
